5. His social values are high and idealistic. His personal
impact on people is generally good - excellent on broad,
high calibered people — good on others. He tends to be
very warm and friendly to those who share some of his
interests, sincere and tolerant but not intensely
warm to those whose interests are mundane and ordinary.
6. His human relations are oriented more towards the
sociological or group than they are towards the psychological
or individual - his interests in broad social principles
and applications is strong. He thinks more often in terms
of group influence and interaction than he does in terms
of individual development.
7. His insights are sharp. He is very contemplative and intro¬
spective person who looks at himself objectively. He
constantly tests what he wants against the possibilities.
His knowledge of his strengths and limitations is excellent.
He is willing to accept himself as he is.
8. His understanding of other people is good, and he has
considerable ability to assess the performance of people
clearly. He has good ability to see the situation fion the
viewpoint of another, although he does not habitually do so.
9. He has good leadership qualities. While neither the high-
pressure salesman nor the rabble-rouser, his poise, purpose
and confidence are communicated to others.
10. He has the patience to teach, guide and direct others. He
will make few organizational mistakes, and will lead
and direct others firmly and consistently. For the long
haul, he will build a smooth organization based on clear
principles and effective teamwork.
Conclusions and Prognosis;
In our opinion, insofar as his psychological qualifications
are concerned, Mr. George A, Bernstein is superior for the
position. He can see the broadest implications of
communications and strives towards long term goals.
He has definite upgrading potential in either staff or
line activities, but it is evident that he will be
utilized most effectively where his creative intelligence
and his verbal effectiveness are challenged. For
maximum personal growth, we suggest that he heighten
his impact on people by being a little more spontaneous,
enthusiastic and free wheeling.
Robert W. Henderson
Consulting Psychologist
May 20, 1952
